DataElement.preferredName: Epithelial Cell Adhesion Molecule Protein Expression BerEP4 IHC Staining Method Result
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Text term that represents the status of the epithelial cell adhesion Molecule (EPCAM) protein expression using BerEP4 immunohistochemistry.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Epithelial Cell Adhesion Molecule Protein Expression BerEp4 IHC Staining Method Performed
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: Epithelial cell adhesion molecule (314 aa, ~35 kDa) is encoded by the human EPCAM gene. This protein is involved in both cell adhesion and cellular proliferation._The biosynthesis of new (often sets of distinct, functionally related) protein products, usually involving new mRNA transcripts, typically in response to an activating stimulus._An immunohistochemical technique utilizing the mouse monoclonal IgG1 antibody BerEp4, which is directed against epithelial cell adhesion molecule (EPCAM). BerEp4 specifically binds to EPCAM, a protein that is selectively expressed in most normal epithelium but not expressed in squamous epithelium and mesothelium. This staining method is used to identify certain cancers and may be used to distinguish neoplasms derived from squamous epithelium and mesothelium from other epithelial-derived neoplasms._Executed and carried through to completion.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Epithelial cell adhesion molecule (314 aa, ~35 kDa) is encoded by the human EPCAM gene. This protein is involved in both cell adhesion and cellular proliferation.

Concepts.definition: Epithelial cell adhesion molecule (314 aa, ~35 kDa) is encoded by the human EPCAM gene. This protein is involved in both cell adhesion and cellular proliferation.

Property.preferredName: Protein Expression BerEp4 IHC Staining Method Performed
Property.preferredDefinition: The biosynthesis of new (often sets of distinct, functionally related) protein products, usually involving new mRNA transcripts, typically in response to an activating stimulus.:An immunohistochemical technique utilizing the mouse monoclonal IgG1 antibody BerEp4, which is directed against epithelial cell adhesion molecule (EPCAM). BerEp4 specifically binds to EPCAM, a protein that is selectively expressed in most normal epithelium but not expressed in squamous epithelium and mesothelium. This staining method is used to identify certain cancers and may be used to distinguish neoplasms derived from squamous epithelium and mesothelium from other epithelial-derived neoplasms.:Executed and carried through to completion.

Concepts.definition: The biosynthesis of new (often sets of distinct, functionally related) protein products, usually involving new mRNA transcripts, typically in response to an activating stimulus.

An immunohistochemical technique utilizing the mouse monoclonal IgG1 antibody BerEp4, which is directed against epithelial cell adhesion molecule (EPCAM). BerEp4 specifically binds to EPCAM, a protein that is selectively expressed in most normal epithelium but not expressed in squamous epithelium and mesothelium. This staining method is used to identify certain cancers and may be used to distinguish neoplasms derived from squamous epithelium and mesothelium from other epithelial-derived neoplasms.
Executed and carried through to completion.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Specification of human conditions relevant to cancer. This includes observations, test results, history, and other concepts relevant to characterization of human cancer-related conditions. Non-neoplastic conditions of interest are also included.

Concepts.definition: Open to question.

PermissibleValues.value: Abnormal null expression (complete loss of expression)

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.: A gradual decline in amount or activity.: The biosynthesis of new (often sets of distinct, functionally related) protein products, usually involving new mRNA transcripts, typically in response to an activating stimulus.

Concepts.definition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.
A gradual decline in amount or activity.
The biosynthesis of new (often sets of distinct, functionally related) protein products, usually involving new mRNA transcripts, typically in response to an activating stimulus.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.: Having strength, power, or intensity greater than average or expected.: Widely spread; not localized or confined.: In biology, to make too many copies of a protein or other substance. Overexpression of certain proteins or other substances may play a role in cancer development.

Concepts.definition: Deviating in any way from the state, position, structure, condition, behavior, or rule which is considered a norm.
Having strength, power, or intensity greater than average or expected.
Widely spread; not localized or confined.
Synthesis of excess polypeptide within the cell. Overexpression is often due to the amplification or deregulation of the gene which encodes the gene product.

The biosynthesis of new (often sets of distinct, functionally related) protein products, usually involving new mRNA transcripts, typically in response to an activating stimulus.
